strTitle: Revitalize Your Skin with a Luxury Facial

strIntroduction: TRADITIONAL BALINESE MASSAGE: This traditional Balinese massage has been passed down from generation to generation to alleviate stress and and loosen muscles using ancestral balinese massage techniques. Hand healing techniques of skin rolling, long kneading strokes, acupressure, and reflexology, are applied combined with a blend of essential oils and specially selected herbs to keep muscles warm. This simulates the lymphatic system and improves blood circulation and the flow of 'Qi' (energy) in your body. Apart from the traditional Balinese massage, you may also select other types of massage treatments listed below. ---------------------------------------- RELAXING BACK MASSAGE (30min): Pause and get the tension kneaded off your shoulders and back. Let the therapist customize the techniques that suit your needs and face the world again with your circulation improved and your mind refreshed. JETLAG STRESS MASSAGE (60min/90min): A good therapy to release water retention and stiff muscles after a long flight or late night out. Relaxing massage techniques combined with a warm compress on your back and legs will bring you back to balance and ready to explore Bali's bests. HAWAIIAN LOMI LOMI MASSAGE (60min/90min): Lomi Lomi is a traditional Hawaiian Healing Massage that treats the mind, body and soul. Lomi Lomi massage involves deeply relaxing, rhythmic, flowing motions that unwind the muscles and release stress. Lomi Lomi has a very caring and luxurious style, with long flowing movements and techniques not used in any other massage. FOUR HANDS MASSAGE (60min/90min): A light/medium pressure synchronized massage performed by 2 therapists. There are no words to describe this amazing one-of-a kind feeling. This signature massage helps to balance your energy and improve blood circulation as well as relieve muscle tension. FOOT REFLEXOLOGY (60min/90min): Originated in China and now loved by all, this health‐enhancing foot therapy focuses on the reflex points of the feet which mirror the entire body system. Stimulating points will assist to restore the natural energy flow and improve circulation. INDIAN HEAD MASSAGE (Indian Champi) (30min): A very effective stress releasing head massage which is based on the ancient Ayurvedic form of healing. It works the upper three chakras to restore physical harmony, vitality, and for good, simple relaxation. ----------------------------------------- All massages will start with a drink of ginger tea to improve blood circulation, and a traditional foot bath ritual to cleanse your feet before beginning the massage.
strTitle: Relax with an Exotic Traditional Balinese Massage

strIntroduction: This Discover Scuba Diving program is a one-off try dive. One of our instructors will take you through a briefing to let you know what happens to your body as you go underwater, after which we’ll teach you some basic skills in the pool and have a swim around to familiarize yourself with the equipment, followed by a dive to 12m in the sea with your instructor. This experience will not teach you to dive, it‘s designed to let you see what diving is all about, and if you like it, you can continue on to the full Open Water course.
strTitle: Introductory Scuba Dive on the Beautiful Gili Islands

strIntroduction: This Open Water Course takes 3-4 days to complete and consists of scuba dive theory (which can be completed here or online before you arrive), confined water training in our pool, and 4 open water dives at world class dive sites located around the Gilis. We have a huge variety of marine life in the area, and over the course of your 4 dives you will have a really good chance of seeing sharks and turtles, as well as some fascinating smaller creatures like octopus, cuttlefish, lionfish and scorpionfish.
strTitle: 3 Day Open Water Dive Course on the Gili Islands

strIntroduction: Snorkel through Bali's beautiful reefs that will amaze your imagination with its plethora of colorful fish and exotic plants. Be fascinated by the wonders of the sea while gliding through the surface of the waters. Feel like one with the aquatic realms surrounding you. Snorkeling is suitable for all ages and abilities, from beginners and young children to advanced swimmers. Those who do not know how to swim can wear a life jacket to help you float. Learning how to breathe through your mouth with the snorkel mask is easy. Free pick-up available from anywhere in Bali!!!
strTitle: Snorkel Through Colorful Fish & Corals in Bali

strIntroduction: This Fishing Tour specialises in deep sea fishing and trolling. Our 11 meter boat is skippered by a fully licensed and highly experienced Captain. On board we carry all the regulated and required safety equipment including a GPRS. The boat contains rest room facilities for your convenience. Experience the thrill of hooking a deep sea fish like Tuna, Blue Marlin and Mackerel. Between catching fish, we also offer snorkeling for your leisure enjoyment. Free pick-up available from anywhere in Bali!!!
strTitle: Join a Deep Sea Fishing Tour

strIntroduction: Up to 5 people can ride on the banana boat together so you can enjoy with your friends and family! A banana boat is a long banana-shaped inflatable craft that you can sit on while being pulled by a speedboat. Expect wind in your hair, splashes of sea water, and loads of fun! Free pick-up available from anywhere in Bali!!! Price is per persom Location : Serangan Island, around 25 min from Kuta by car
strTitle: Go on a Banana Boat Ride in Bali

strIntroduction: Fancy sitting on a donut, being rocked and pulled by a speed boat at top exhilarating speeds. The donut boat is very similar to the banana boat, with the exception of its donut shape. 2-4 people can sit on the boat and how fast you go is based on your request. Free pick-up available from Kuta, Seminyak, Jimbaran, Legian, Nusa Dua, Sanur. (min 2person Booking)
strTitle: Take a Ride on a Donut Boat

strIntroduction: Since ancient times, people have been intrigued by these gifts from the sea... While natural pearls are still found "in the wild", most are now farmed and cultured to meet the world's demand for these beautiful organic gems. If you are interested in seeing what goes on behind the scenes at a world-renowned pearl company, this is a fascinating tour you won't want to miss! Our showroom and cafe is perched over the warm waters of Teluk Nara harbour, only 25 minutes drive north of Senggigi. During this tour, we walk you through our laboratories step-by-step, showing you the hatchery and the plankton lab while giving you insight into what goes into culturing a perfect pearl. We will show you how we painstakingly grow the microscopic oysters to size and kickstart the pearl culture process. You will also get to see the oysters in various stages of development. As a final highlight, we will even extract a pearl from a real oyster, so you get to see what the final gem looks like. Our tour ends with a leisurely coffee or refreshing cool drink at our floating cafe, which offers splendid views of the Rinjani mountain range to the north and the famous Gili Islands to the east. Before you go, we will also give you a personal lesson on evaluating pearls, so you are equipped with the knowledge and understanding needed to choose your own pearl in the future! Available every day from 10am to 3pm (tour upon request).
strTitle: Visit a Local Pearl Farm and See How Pearls are Cultured

strIntroduction: Depending on what you'd like to see, we have a number of different biking options for you to enjoy the backroads and daily life in Lombok. In order of popularity Benang Stokel Waterfall Biking Tour (Most popular) This full day biking tour is a popular route for bikers who want to sightsee on scenic back roads to visit famous spots in Lombok such as temples, pottery villages, weaving villages, rice fields and waterfalls (with minimum time spent biking through the main road). This trip will bring you closer to the nature where you can learn and see how locals really live. The ride will start by the west, south of Mataram, and we will isit Pengsong Temple, then proceed to Banyumulek Villages to see the locals work, before we continue to Sukarara village and finish at the incredible Benang Setokel Waterfall. After that, we bike back thourgh Suranadi, Lingsar and back to Senggigi where you will enjoy the rest of the day at your hotel. Narmada Water Palace Biking Tour Our day starts with pick up at your hotel in Senggigi (or other areas), then we drop you at Mapak Village (around 45 minutes away) and then start biking through the back roads of Mataram. We then continue to Banyumulek Village (Pottery Village ) to see how to make a pottery by hand and then go direct to Kuripan Village for a lunch break (already prepared by our team ). Lastly, we go directly to Narmada, where our transport waiting for us to back to Sengigigi or your hotel. Medas Hill Biking Tour Our day starts with pick up at your hotel in Senggigi (or other areas), then we drop you at Tanah Embet Village (a short 15 minute ride away ) to start Your Adventure Tour biking through to the villages and then to Medas Hill ( 900 m). You can take pictures from the top with a spectacular panoramic view, bike down through the rice fields and then finish at the oldest traditional SASAK House at Karang Bayan. A car will be waiting for you at this village to take back you to Senggigi /your hotel.
strTitle: Full Day Biking Tour of Lombok with Locals

strIntroduction: This long route bike trip was designed for those who want to circle the lombok island with a push bike.The entire trip will take approximately 3 to 4 days of biking, and we will spend the night in north lombok (Senaru village), in east lombok (Tete batu village ), and in south lombok (Kuta ) and finish at Senggigi. A dedicated car and support team will always be there during the trip, so members of your cycling group can take a break at any time. Day 1 : Start at 7am Pick up by your tour guide at your hotel Then start your bike ride through the coast side to Bangsal harbour by stopping at Malimbu or Nipah hill for the best view of the Gili Islands ( Trawangan, Meno and Air) from the top of hilly road. On this road, you will ride up and downhill until you reach Pemenang town, then the road will be rather flat until Bayan district. However, before you reach Bayan, you will stop by Tampes beach for lunch, a rest and some swimming at the black sandy beach which will refresh you just before you continue your ride to Senaru village. This first day, you will ride for 89 km to the northern coast of Lombok Island, and you will arrive in the afternoon. You can then check into the hotel and have the rest of the evening free. Day 2 : Start at 7am After breakfast, continue your bike ride to north east Lombok, with a stop at the oldest mosque at Bayan bekek village. This mosque was built in early 16th century by the son of Sunan Bonang, Sunan Perapen. Then, we proceed to Obel beach where you stop for a rest and a swim at the black sand beach where most of the people are fisherman. These fishermen still use small simple fishing boats to go fishing, which is really interesting to see. After you feel fresh, you will then continue your ride to Sambelia village for a stop at the giant tree forest. Lunch will be at Labuan Lombok, afterwhich we continue to Tete Batu in the afternoon. You can then check into the hotel and have the rest of the evening free. Day 3 : Start at 7am After breakfast we will ride to the southern coast of Lombok. This road is a little easier, because you will ride down to the capital city of central Lombok. Then the road is rather flat to Kuta, Lombok. On the way to Kuta, we will stop at a traditional Sasak village so you can see how the sasak people spend their days. Not long after that, we will arrive at Kuta Lombok Beach where you can check into the hotel and have the rest of the evening free. Day 4 : Start at 7am After breakfast, we ride our bikes back to Senggigi. On the way back, you may to stop in at some traditional wood carving villages, Sukarara hand weaving village, Banyumulek pottery village, and various scenic temples along the way. In the afternoon, you will arrive at Senggigi, triumphant from a fantastic trip to see the best the lush island has to offer.
strTitle: Four Day Biking Trip to see the Real Lombok!

strIntroduction: Depending on what you'd like to see, you can pick from any of the 4 routes below which are a great introduction to Lombok! The first two are very relaxing for bikers of all levels, and the next two are for those more interested in seeing rural life. Biking Tour to Pengsong Hill : There is a pura ( temple ) in the hilly area honored by hindu worshipers. From here, you will see beautiful natural scenery and the harmonious natural lifestyle of the locals. You will have an unforgettable view of farmers tending the land blended together with Mother nature. Here live families of tame monkeys we will say hello to. The hill was even once used by the Japanese as a hiding place during World War II. Biking Tour to Lingsar / Waktu Telu : Lingsar is a unique and sacred temple of two beliefs. Hindus and Muslims who worship together in one place. It was built around 1714 and every November and December, Pujawali dan Perang Ketupat ceremonies are held, carried out together by hindus followers and the sasak ethnic group expressing their thanks to God who has given them well being during the year. You will ride around the villages and rice terrace fields and see the smiling faces of the locals. Biking Tour to Sekotong / South of Lombok : - We will drive you to Sekotong peninsula from Senggigi where you will begin your cycling journey. - Most of the beaches on the way are pure white sand, with some of the best vistas you will ever see. - We will spend about 5 hours or maybe more exploring the beautiful coastline in the south. Biking Tour to Pusuk Forest : - You will start in the rain forest at 500 meters above sea level - You will be able to see the northern sea through a green valley with forest and rice fields. - Groups of wild monkeys will line up on the road waiting for peanuts or fruits, which make for a fun adventure.
strTitle: Enjoy a Half Day Bike Ride around Lombok with Locals

strIntroduction: If you have limited time in Bali, this day of adventure will give you a great taste of the beautiful Balinese countryside. We'll bring you the best of the best - with village cycling to meet the locals, Bali Elephant Camp to meet our gentle giants, and finally an exhilarating rafting tour down the Ayung River. FULL DAY ITINERARY: 08.00 – 08.15: Depart from hotel 09.15 – 09.30: Arrive at cycling starting point, registration & coffee break 09.30 – 09.45: Safety talk, outfit equipment & start cycling 10.00 – 10.15: Enter Bali Elephant Camp, tropical welcome drink served 10.30 – 10.45: Ride the elephant for 30 minutes 11.15 – 11.30: Finish riding, continue cycling 13.00 – 13.15: Finish cycling, visit Sangeh monkey forest, transferred to restaurant 13.15 – 13.30: Lunch, transferred to rafting starting point 14.30 – 14.45: Safety talk & start rafting 17.00 – 17.15: Finish rafting, take a shower 17.45 – 18.00: Drive back to hotel 19.00 – 19.15: Arrive at hotel MORE ABOUT EACH ACTIVITY: BALI VILLAGE CYCLING Takes you through the back roads of the famous Carang Sari Village where you can glimpse the real life and culture of these amazing people. Cruise through untouched rice paddies, pass the Bali Elephant Camp for a quick stop just to get a picture of this huge biggest animal. Enjoy the local scenery and visit the Sangeh Monkey Forest to meet its cheeky inhabitants. ELEPHANT TREK: Befriend a great Sumatran elephant on our Adventurer Trek! Safely perched on the broad back of this majestic giant, you will plunge into a verdant tropical landscape, catching glimpses of chattering monkeys and colorful birds, as the trail follows the the banks of the raging Ayung River. At the end of the ride, your intelligent mount will cool off in the wading pool (while carefully keeping you high and dry) before delivering you to the Trunk'n'Mahout' cafe for refreshments overlooking the stunning valley scenery. WHITE WATER RAFTING Experience the Bali's singular approach to white-water rafting with a morning or afternoon excursion down the sacred Ayung River winding through the heartland of the island. During two hours of tranquil drifting punctuated by thrilling moments of shooting the rapids, you will Discover hidden waterfalls, swim in the pristine water, and gain insight into river ecology and Balinese daily life from our expert and knowledgeable guides. The experience ends at Karang Dalem with a hot shower! PRICE INCLUDES: *Welcome drink (free flow coffee & tea) *Air conditioned return transfer *Professional river and cycling guide as well as mahout *International standard safety equipment *Cool face towel *Waterproof bag on each boat to keep valuable belongings *Entrance fee to Sangeh monkey forest *Entrance fee to Bali Elephant Camp + tropical welcome drink *A bottle of mineral water during cycling *Lunch + one complimentary soft drink *Shower facilities + towel *US$ 150,000 International Insurance Cover
strTitle: Full Day Tour: Village Cycling + Elephant Trek + Rafting

strIntroduction: Our bike ride takes you through the back roads of the famous Carangsari Village, birth place of Bali's national hero 'Ngurah Rai, where you can get an authentic glimpse the daily life and culture of these amazing people. Cruise through untouched rice paddies, pass by Bali Elephant Camp for a quick stop just to get a picture of these beautiful creatures. After you enjoy the local scenery, we pay a visit to the Sangeh Monkey Forest to meet its cheeky macaques. You’ll stop several times along this route as we pass through unspoiled rice terraces and traditional houses and temples. At any point along this leisurely ride, you can stop to meet friendly locals, take photos of scenic spots, and learn about the local culture. Lunch is served overlooking a panoramic view of Ubud.
strTitle: Go Village Cycling around the Scenic Carangsari Village

strIntroduction: Because it is situated at the connection between the Pacific Ocean and the Indian Ocean, in the middle of the worlds richest marine bio-geographical area, Bali boasts some of the best dive sites in the world! Diving is much easier than you think, so come ready to take advantage of this amazing natural beauty! This day is designed to be your chance to get wet and experience what scuba diving is all about, and decide whether getting a scuba diving certification is right for you. We know that once you come in and try it, you’ll love it! During this experience, you will have an Instructor as your personal escort, and prior to your dive, we will provide you with an overview of the proper knowledge and skills required to take your first look at the beautiful underwater world of Bali. As soon as you have finished your program you will be awarded with a digital certificate. Come enjoy the beauty of the underwater world of Bali with us and let yourself be surprised by the results.
strTitle: Try Scuba Diving For the First Time

strIntroduction: After a short moment to enjoy the stunning views and a cool drink at my restaurant Bali Asli, you will follow our trekking guide who will take you "through the looking glass" up into the village of Pangi, where you will have the opportunity to peek into the daily life of the Balinese. Our trekking guide will explain Balinese culture and the intricacies of Balinese life as you walk past village temples and peer over moss-clad walls to understand how a Balinese house and its temple are designed. In addition to enjoying stunning views over rice fields, ocean and volcanoes, you will visit a local and his son who make "tuak" or Balinese palm wine. The group will then wander through coconut groves and cassava plantations, under water apple trees and past pineapples before coming across a small traditional Balinese home. You will be invited in for morning coffee and traditional sweets. Lastly, descend to a natural spring where the local gather holy water. This is where you can bathe your feet in the springs of the valley of Tauke before wandering through the rice fields back to the restaurant to start your cooking class.
strTitle: A day in the village

strIntroduction: My friend Pak Dewa will take you on a tour of his village community, where you can join in the daily activities as well as learn about traditional Balinese agricultural techniques and taste “Jamu” - the Indonesian elixir of life. We start the day by joining Pak Dewa at his village temples as he teaches us about the important act of placing offerings every day before he can start work. We then wander through his village community garden where we'll see some villagers standing in the muddy paddies planting rice. We can jump in and have fun helping them. We continue on and arrive at the old foundations of Dewa's grandmas house where his auntie and wife have prepared morning tea for us! Dewa teaches us how to make a traditional medicine called "Jamu " and his wife demonstrates how to weave coconut palm leaves in to various intricate woven palm leaf parcels that we will use as part of our Balinese cooking class. We sit and sip the rich home-made Bali coffee in the shade of a papaya plantation and chat about Balinese daily life and culture. After a relaxing morning tea we wander back through the village and return to my restaurant Bali Asli (see the amazing view in our pictures). At Bali Asli you will learn about the local produce used to make medicines, offerings and how it is also used in traditional cooking techniques, and of course guided through the steps to create an authentic Balinese lunch.
strTitle: A day in the life of a Balinese farmer

strIntroduction: Join me on this fun adventure as Bapak Sahnon, our local fisherman from Bug-Bug village, helps you aboard his traditional style jukung out-rigger sailing boat to join the rest of the fishing fleet in the crystal clear waters around the small islands just off Pasir Putih beach in East Bali. Our day starts with an offering to the goddess of the ocean to ensure a prosperous and safe fishing trip. Bapak Wayan also places a "canang " or offering with perfumed incense on his boat before you slide off the the smooth white sand into the glistening blue ocean of the East Coast of Bali. The views of the coast line and Mount Agung are so stunning, you'll almost forget you're fishing! After about 1.5 languid hours, you return to the beach and drive 15 minutes to my scenic restaurant Bali Asli to start our cooking class. First we are introduced to our ingredients, by smelling and tasting them raw. Then we start our hands-on class. Lunch consists of what we cook - about 7 different dishes - including the fish that were caught earlier! If you would prefer to skip the cooking class and instead have lunch cooked by our chefs, you can choose from 2 lunch menus: Megibung or Nasi Campur *********************** MEGIBUNG LUNCH (sample menu) - Home-made Krupuk and 4 types of sambal - Jukut kelor meliklik A fragrant broth made from young coconut, sweet corn and magical kelor leaves - Nasi sele Steamed organic Balinese rice with sweet potato from my neighbour's garden - Urab paku dan don kacang panjang Young fern tips plucked from the nearby gullies, with long bean leaves, sweet red chilli and freshly grated coconut - Don labu, kacang merah me santan Steamed pumpkin leaves and red beans dressed with Balinese spices, tiny limes and coconut milk - Sate ikan laut katek papah, sambal kecicang Fisherman fresh sea fish sate with ginger flower and lime leaf sambal -Sambal udang Wok tossed prawns with a spicy tomato sauce - Brengkes tahu Locally-made tofu, shallots, ginger, lemon basil, tamarind and chilli wrapped in banana leaves and steamed - Sambal telor puyuh Spicy quail eggs, with runny centers and paddy herbs - Dessert Market fresh local fruits and home-made Balinese cakes Bali coffee or Indonesian tea NASI CAMPUR LUNCH (sample menu) - Home-made Krupuk and 4 types of sambal - Nasi sele Steamed organic Balinese rice with sweet potato from my neighbour's garden - Urab paku dan don kacang panjang Young fern tips plucked from the nearby gullies, with long bean leaves, sweet red chilli and freshly grated coconut - Don labu, kacang merah me santan Steamed pumpkin leaves and red beans dressed with Balinese spices, tiny limes and coconut milk - Sate ikan laut katek papah, sambal kecicang Fisherman fresh sea fish sate with ginger flower and lime leaf sambal - Brengkes tahu Locally-made tofu, shallots, ginger, lemon basil, tamarind and chilli wrapped in banana leaves and steamed -Tempe manis Slices of fermented soy bean cake and peanuts tossed in a delicately spiced caramel
strTitle: Experience a Day in the Life of a Balinese Fisherman

strIntroduction: We have a very unfortunate young boy in our orphanage. His name is Risal and he is eleven years old. He's a lovely child, full of energy, with the warmest smile in the world. But he requires an expensive operation to be performed in Singapore. The condition this young boy has is called Hypospadias. He already took one operation - it was performed in September 2013, which was sponsored by a generous donor. A second procedure is required in six months time however. We don't have the necessary funds, to sponsor his second operation. We are doing our best, but any help you can give us would be helping us to make it happen.
strTitle: Help Risal Undergo his difficult Operation

strIntroduction: Music is an important part of the children's life at Jodie O'Shea and we have some very talented young musicians here. Some of them have been accepted to enter Indonesia's music competitions. We see these little kids' passion and see them playing all the time, even by themselves. We want them to continue their music education, give them a change develop their skills and passion. In order to continue with this, they require music lessons. Music lessons are held every Saturday for six students. Professional teacher comes in and conducts the lessons. The cost is 1.8M Rupiah (about $160) for 4 sessions.
strTitle: Sponsor Piano Lessons for talented Orphans

strIntroduction: At Jodie O'Shea we not only want to raise our children in a loving environment, but we also want to prepare them to a life in society and equip them with skills that will help them in their adult lives. That's why we started giving Computer Lessons. The children have two classes per week. As part of the sponsorship program, the older children are encouraged to develop their own Facebook page so that they can talk in English with their sponsor. Computer skills and learning English is an important part of their development , as one of Bali's main industries is Tourism. Having both of these skills, the children will have an excellent standing for working in the tourism industry. All of the computers as well as the furniture have been donated already. Classes cost 1M Rupiah for eight classes. As part of our strategy plan we would like to upgrade the computers in the next 12 months. We, and our little kids, will be grateful for any help you can provide!
strTitle: Aid in funding Computer Lessons for Children in Orphanage

strIntroduction: Want to do something unique in Bali? Bring a extraordinary present for someone you care about? Try our Silver Jewelry classes! We will meet in a studio in the center of Ubud, where the Jewelry Class will take place. Our staff will take good care of you and explain everything before you get started. You can choose what to make from our different designs. You will definitely find something for yourself; it doesn't matter how skilled you are. The whole class will take about three hours. Our staff will assist you and make sure your finished piece will look beautiful. The class includes 5 grams of silver. That's enough for earrings or a necklace, but it would probably take more material to make a wristband. You can buy additional silver on the spot, if you require.
strTitle: Present Someone you Care about with Handmade Jewelry

strIntroduction: Enter the most awesome battlefield in Bali - where winning and losing is decided in a split of a second. Here, you will discover a fun way to feed your adrenaline hunger while developing valuable tactical skills and resistance to stress which are also useful in everyday life. Cooperate with some of your friends and play against others, strengthening your bonds, while having tons of fun. Our paintball center is the only facility with 2 playing fields in Bali, covering over a 2-hectares of land. You can play all the games you wish there - classical team vs team, capture the flag, or anything else you can imagine! We stock the latest imported equipment for your safety and full satisfaction. The facility is complemented by our expert staff to ensure an exciting and pleasurable visit. Round trip transfer to/from: Nusa Dua, Jimbaran, Kuta, Seminyak, Denpasar and Sanur is included.
strTitle: Battle Your Friends at an Exhilarating Paintball Game

strIntroduction: *This dinner requires a minimum of 15 participants. Hayam Wuruk was the ruler of the Javanese Hindu Empire of Majapahit. He inherited the throne at the age of sixteen, when the great Patih, the prime minister, Gajah Mada was at the height of his power. Under Wayam Wuruk’s reign, the Majapahit empire extended its supremacy throughout the sprawling archipelago that later became known as the East Indies, and eventually Indonesia. The Royal TUGUDOM dining experience tells the story of the grand dining ceremonies of the royal expeditions of King Hayam Wuruk of the Majapahit Kingdom through vast areas, including Bali. The Majapahit royal entourage traveled on foot, with buffalo-drawn carts, horses and elephants, from the eastern region of Java to Bali, stopping at temples, markets, villages, and ‘tugus’, the monuments of the God of Çiwa. In this special Royal Tugudom dinner, a parade of staff appears in the costumes of the villagers, soldiers and dancers who would attend to the King and his entourage, and they serve you just as they might a Royal guest, loving every moment of the charade that takes all participants back to a glorious time of feasting and merriment. Come and experience this amazing dining experience we are well-known for. MENU 1st Course: Tum Be Siap, Lawar Gedang Kaba, Otak-Otak Tahu Tempe Pocket of Chicken, Indian Bay Leaves and Exotic Herbs Grated Young Papaya in Balinese Spices; Soybean Cake and Tofu Stewed in Banana Leaves 2nd Course: Kuah Be Pasih Blimbing Wuluh Soup of Snapper, Clams, Shrimps and Baby Starfruits Main: Nasi Kuning Turmeric Rice Nasi Brongkos Rice Steamed in Ground Kluwek Nut (Black Nut) Tahu Tempe Bumbu Bacem Island Tofu and Soybean Cake, Stewed in Tamarind Sauce Ayam Panggang Bumbu Besengek Grilled Chicken, Marinated in Turmeric, Coconut Milk, and Candlenut Lobster Jayanagara Grilled Lobster in Stew of Garlic and Toasted Fresh Coconut Udang Bumbu Rujak Prawns in Red Curry Sate Lilit Gianyar Balinese Minced Fish Satay with “Sambal Matah” Bebek Betutu Famous Balinese Duck Slow-Roasted in Banana Leaves with 12 Spices Lawar Don Blimbing Desa Buit Starfruit Leaves in Ground Coriander Seed, Candlenut, Shallot, Garlic, and Coconut Milk Sayur Lombok Hijau Iwak Asin Chayote Squash, Green and Red Pepper, Salted Fish Rempeyek Giant Homemade Crackers Last: Es Telung Canggu Sorbets of Tamarillo, Passionfruit and Jackfruit Coconut with Tropical Fruit Cocktail Kopi / Teh Plantation Coffee and Tea
strTitle: Experience a Ceremonial Dinner of the Majapahit Kingdom

strIntroduction: Our Royal Balinese dining room - Bale Puputan - was built in tribute to the Balinese Heroes who sacrificed their lives during the “Battle to the Last Man” against the Dutch Colonialism. With this special dinner, we welcome guests to enjoy the comfort of the antique regal armchairs while they dine at the largest 19th century whole marble table in the country, surrounded by antique statues representing the creatures of Balinese mythology. We want you to experience the elegant imperial dining of the Balinese kings and princes as they lived at the beginning of the Dutch colonial era. The dishes are presented on Dulang (Balinese-style Wooden Offering Plate) and some of the regally fine and traditional Balinese dishes served include Babi Guling (a whole Suckling Pig), Bebek Betutu (Roasted Duck that is cooked in coconut husks for twenty-four hours), Jukut Meurab (Marinated Vegetables in Grilled Coconut), Lawar Kacang (Marinated Long Beans and Chicken) and Jukut Ares (Banana Stem Soup with Chicken). MENU Nasi Putih Steamed Rice *** Nasi Kuning Turmeric Yellow Rice *** Jukut Ares Chicken and Young Banana Stem Soup *** Bebek Betutu Usually prepared for religious ceremonies, this whole duck roasted in banana leaf has become the signature dish of Bali. The traditional cooking method followed is by stuffing and covering the duck with various herbs & spices, covering it with banana leaf, and then roasting it in a firewood oven for at least 12 hours *** Guling Celeng Another Balinese Signature Dish of Tender Roasted Suckling Pig *** Sate Udang Sereh Grill Prawn on Lemongrass *** Tum Ayam Steam Chicken and Herbs in Banana Leaves *** Jukut Meurab Steamed Vegetables in Spicy Grated Coconut *** Lawar Kacang Traditional Balinese Long Bean and Chicken Salad *** Kacang Goreng Fried Peanut *** Samsam Balinese Crisp Fried Pork Skin *** Aneka Jajan Bali Balinese Sweets
strTitle: Dine like a Balinese King in an Antique-filled Room

strIntroduction: If you're looking to have fun making your own jewelry in a traditional Balinese compound near the artist haven we call Ubud, you and your whole family are welcome in my home, where you will meet my family and neighbours who often come by to say hello. Usually we begin our class at 9.30am or 1.30pm, and start with the basics of picking out the items you'd like to use. These range from rings, pendants, necklaces to earrings. I have a catalogue here that'll help you think of ideas. Then, the appropriate size of silver is cut for you to get started; we help guide you along the process of filing, sanding and shaping your jewelry. You can also bring your own pre-made design that we can try to help you materialize! We have been running this class for years and have a great reputation, so don't hesitate to bring your families, children, or friends over to craft your very own handmade souvenir from Bali.
strTitle: Learn to Fashion your own Silver Jewelry in Ubud

strIntroduction: Djamoe is a mixture of traditional herbs and spices, which are used for healing and rejuvenation. Traditional ‘Djamoe’ comes from the island of Java, and has evolved over hundred of years through the generations. The Djamoes consist of leafs, roots, flowers and barks of significant trees. Through generations, for more than hundred of years, the Javanese have been doing research and making observations through trials and experiences to get the real use of all those herbs and spices which are found in their surroundings. Learn the traditional way of preparing 4 kinds of these mixture and their benefits for health, beauty and longevity. Here are some examples of the drinks we can make: Djamoe for weight loss and fat reduction (Djamoe Mengkudu or Djamoe Cabe Puyang) Djamoe for energy and to cure muscle aches (Djamoe Beras Kencur) Djamoe for smooth skin (Djamoe Kunir Asem) Djamoe for cholesterol reduction (Djamoe Daun Salam) The class will take about 1.5 - 2hours and I am flexible on starting time
strTitle: Learn to Make Traditional Javanese Herbal Drinks in Canggu

strIntroduction: Known for its authentic traditional Indonesian food in Bali and Java, Hotel Tugu Bali is a place that aims to opens the doors to a glimpse into the beautiful simplicity and the exotic richness of Indonesian dining and cooking culture. Commencing in the morning, you begin by choosing the dishes you'd most prefer from my large collection of Javanese and Balinese recipes. A visit to a Balinese traditional market follows where all the freshest ingredients of the archipelago of islands, once known as the Spice Islands, can be found amidst the daily bustle of modern day market life. While gathering the ingredients for the cooking class you will be involved in and experience first-hand the Balinese way of daily living, the jovial and sometimes noisy bargaining style of the vendors and buyers... MENU Please select 5 dishes from the selection for your Cooking Class program. If you have any favorite dishes that you would like to learn, please let us know and I will be happy to accommodate it. Sample Traditional Javanese Menu: • Nasi Goreng Jawa/ Stir-fried rice in traditional Javanese spices • Botok Daging/ Minced marinated beef, cooked in banana leaves • Sambal Goreng Udang/ Marinated shrimps and potatoes in red pepper • Lodeh Tewel Tahu Tempe/ Stew of young jackfruit, soybean cake and tofu in coconut milk • Ayam Panggang Bumbu Terik/ Grilled chicken, marinated in coconut milk and various spices Sample Traditional Balinese Menu: • Sambal Matah/ Balinese shallot & lemongrass dressing • Pesan Bepasih/ Steamed Balinese fish in lemongrass, wrapped in banana leaves • Sate Lilit/ Lemongrass skewers of minced fish in various spices • Lawar Kacang/ Marinated long bean and chicken salads • Jukut Ares/ Banana stem soup • Ayam Pelalah/ The popular fare of Balinese shredded chicken ITINERARY: Class (with Market Visit) Approximate duration: 6.5 hours 07.00: Depart your hotel 07.45: Arrive at Market 09.45: Arrive at Tugu Bali 09.45: Optional light breakfast (not included, can be ordered from the a la carte menu) 10.00: Start cooking class 12.30: Lunch is serviced 13.30: Return to hotel Class (without Market Visit) 09.00: Depart your hotel 09.45: Arrive at Tugu Bali 10.00: Start cooking class 12.30: Lunch is serviced 13.30: Return to hotel
strTitle: Study Traditional Indonesian Cuisine with Mrs Soelastri

strIntroduction: There are dozens of dances in Bali, the first step is to learn basic gestures of Legong for ladies or Baris for men. Join us in our commitment to keep alive the dying ancestral dances that form the heart of Balinese culture and religious ceremonies. You may choose 2 dances to be learned per class from dance list below: • Topeng (Mask Dance): considered as sacred object, every mask is believed to possess spirits that must be captured by the dancer’s own. • Barong: this dance represents the struggle between the Good and the Evil; Good being personified by Barong Ketet and Evil by Rangda. • Legong: Performed by three dancers - the first character seen on the stage being a Condong (a female clown) and the other two representing the princess • Rangkesari of Daha and King Lasem, who forcibly carries off Rangkesari • Panyem Brama: dance usually used to welcome and greet people • Kebyar Duduk: Kebyar means a sudden flare or flash. The style is a clear example of the direct relationship between music and dance • Baris: With heroic poses and fiercely determined facial expression, this dance is an abstract character – study of a warrior Inseparable from the dances, gamelan is the traditional music instrument used either as a singular performance or as the other half of a theater/dance performance of equal importance. Gamelan consists of various different instruments that make one whole orchestra—pick your favorite and indulge yourself in the sea of exotic sounds.
strTitle: Learn to Master the 7 Ancestral Balinese Dances

strIntroduction: While many guests come to Bali to see the sights, they may not get a chance to experience life as a Balinese. With this special itinerary I've created, I hope to combine both and give you a peek into daily Balinese life with a trip to my home town of Munduktemu, an overnight stay with a local family and stops at many key landmarks on our beautiful island. Firstly, I will take you to our world-famous pilgrimage temple Tanah Lot. This temple is set on a large offshore rock and has been part of Balinese mythology for centuries. We will then drive through Kerambitan village in Tabanan regency, famous for its stunning view of rice paddy fields on either side of the road . After about an hour's drive, we make a stop at the quiet Sanda village, to have lunch in one of the local restaurants, where you get to see the different dishes we enjoy as locals. Next, we continue the trip to Pupuan to see beautiful rice paddy terraces on the way to my home town Munduktemu. From the main road, we will take a leisurely 1 km stroll to my family farm, which is a salak fruit, or snake fruit farm. This unique fruit is as common to us as apples or oranges are to Americans in the U.S. Strawberry-sized and fig-shaped, the fruit comes encased in vivid, nutty-brown scales, not unlike that of a cobra or python. Heaps of salaks turn up daily at countless local markets, but here you will get to see how we grow them. In the evening I will take you to another relaxed village called Pupuan in the Tabanan regency, where you can stay in one the local guest houses to experience life with a Balinese family. The next day, we drive back from Pupuan to your hotel via Munduk to see the tallest waterfall in Bali, the gorgeous twin mountain lakes Buyan and Tamblingan as well as Lake Bratan, which boasts Bali's famous "temple on a lake" - Puru Ulun Danu Bratan. Our last stop will be at Jatiluwih, a UNESCO world heritage site boasting beautiful contoured terraces that make up the largest rice paddy fields in Asia.
strTitle: Visit my Hometown and See the Best of Bali too

strIntroduction: In the area of lake Beratan, in the scenic Bedugul region near Mount Mangu, where the temperature is always cool, farmers have planted beautiful strawberries which are a wonderful treat. Since it never freezes, these strawberries grow all year around, and you can enjoy beautiful scenic views and fresh mountain air as you make your way to the strawberry garden. Our first stop of the day though will be at Pacung mountain to enjoy the view of the rice paddy fields with Mt Batukaru and Mt Catur in the background. We continue our trip with a visit to a vegetable market where you can observe the local farmers trading their products, and then proceed to Strawberry garden to pick strawberry. After you pick 1 or 2 kg of strawberries, we will drive through the Botanical garden and stop for a relaxing picnic. If you still have energy, you may also give tree top climbing and flying foxes a go. Our last stop for the day will be at Gobleg hill to enjoy the best Goreng Pisang (or deep fried bananas - a popular local dessert) in the area.
strTitle: Pick Strawberries on an Authentic Balinese Farm

strIntroduction: The Balinese tradition of salt farming dates back almost a thousand years. This natural sea salt is harvested from the top surface of crystallized, unspoiled, sea water by the small farmers of Kusamba village, a traditional Balinese fishing village. Many generations have benefited from Kusamba’s unique geographical location, using their conventional method of harvesting, to produce natural salt with a truly distinctive texture and subtle flavour. This could be the last generation of salt farmers on Bali, and I am excited to bring you to see them before they disappear. When we get to Kusamba village, you will be able to try your hand at the process, first using teku-teku - a sea water container made of palm stem - to carry the sea water to a drying area. You then splash the water on this black sand, walking while shaking the teku-teku. The evaporation of seawater in the beds of black volcanic sands create pure distilled brine. The brine is then left to crystallise inside vessels made from coconut tree logs. The crystal salts that emerge on the surface of the brine are hand-raked and drained to remove the excess brine. You will be able to watch the villagers complete the process and even purchase this precious salt as a great souvenir. To complete an exciting day out however, we first make a pit stop at Kertagosa, the royal court of justice, where you can learn about the history of the kings of Klungkung from 1536 to 1908. After our time at Kusamba, we continue our journey to Tenganan village for a fascinating look at "ancient Bali". This is one of Bali's Aga villages - meaning its residents are considered the 'original' Balinese people and they maintain the original traditions and rules of ancient Bali, such as house design, religious ritual ceremony, and general way of life. Finally, we stop at the Tirtagangga water palace, whose gardens, huge koi fish and spring fed swimming pools are an amazing sight for some great photographs. We take a break for a simple lunch here, then head back through Bandem, a "snakefruit plantation village" which grows this ubiquitous Indonesian fruit.
strTitle: Observe the Balinese Tradition of Salt Farming

strIntroduction: This Personal Shopping Program is designed with your comfort and convenience in mind. I will take you to a variety of shops, galleries and retail outlets, as well as the best suppliers of antique and modern teak furniture, home and garden furnishings and stone building materials. I can assist you in sourcing the following items : antique furniture, artefacts and accessories teak garden, patio furniture, natural and synthetic rattan furniture gazebos, bales and pre-fabricated buildings skilfully-crafted doors, windows and flooring stone carvings and stone building materials terracotta and cement pots wood carvings and handicrafts ceramics and hand blown glass silver and beaded jewelry silk, cotton, linen and rayon clothing hand woven ikat cloth and blankets world famous batik masks and puppets basketry and natural fibre furnishings wall hangings, bedspreads and sarongs paintings and decorative art handmade paper products
strTitle: Shop till you Drop in Bali

strIntroduction: I have been taking guests around for some time now, but one of the most unique trips I know of in Bali is a trip to the ancient village of Trunyan... We combine this visit with several other site of interest to make your day worthwhile! ABOUT TRUNYAN: Untouched by modern influences, Trunyan is particularly known for its kuburan or cemetery, located about 500 meters outside the village. The village's method of dispatching the dead is particularly intriguing, as the villagers don't believe in cremation and instead choose a weathering burial. Essentially, the villagers cover the bodies of the deceased with a white cloth and proceed to conduct lengthy rituals. A bamboo cage surrounds the body, which is then left to the elements. You will be able to see this macabre collection of skulls and bones lying on the stone platform and the surrounding areas. It will be a completely surreal experience! The village also houses several traditional Bali Aga-style dwellings, and a large banyan tree, which is said to be more than 1, 100 years old. SUGGESTED ITINERARY - 08. 30 Leave hotel - 09. 30 Batu Bulan village; Barong & Kris dance performance. - 11. 00 Tohpati village; Traditional hand weaving cloth/ Batik - 11. 45 Mas village; House of traditional wood carving. - 12. 30 Tegalalang ; the most beautiful rice fields terraces in Bali - 13. 15 Coffee and cacao plantation. - 14. 00 Kintamani ; Fascinating Volcano & lake Batur ( buffet lunch ) - 15. 30 Trunyan ; Original Bali Aga village. - 16. 30 Toya Bungkah ; natural hot spring. - 18. 30 Back to hotel
strTitle: Visit an Ancient Village, Kintamani Volcano and Hot Springs

strIntroduction: Take part in a fascinating downhill cycling tour from Mount Batur (Kintamani Village) and through Bali's beautiful quiet countryside back roads. We will take you to a woodcarving workshop, temples, coffee plantation, and rice paddy fields. Get a taste of local fruits, vegetables and herbal teas along the way. Here is our program for the day: -Morning pick-up at your hotel before we drive to the countryside. - Pay a visit to the famous Tegallalang rice terraces. - Visit a plantation where the famous Luwak coffee is produced. - Enjoy a traditional Balinese breakfast with breathtaking views over the active volcano Mount Batur and Batur Lake. - Enjoy a pleasant downhill ride with beautiful views. - Walk through the rice paddies and understand the process of rice growing. - Visit a traditional woodcarving workshop. - Savour lunch in a traditional Balinese family home
strTitle: Cycle From Mount Batur Through Bali's Countryside

strIntroduction: If you are have heard about the curious Balinese fruit called the snakeskin fruit, you will be interested to witness the 14 varieties grown in this majestic village. Close to the foot of the majestic and still active Mt Agung in North East Bali, Dukuh Sibetan villagers are only too aware of their precarious existence. When the volcano erupted in 1963, sand and rocks blanketed the village farmlands, making a return to normal agriculture impossible. One of the few crops that were able to survive in these new conditions, however, was salak- the snakeskin fruit, already present in the area for hundreds of years. Thus, the farmers of Dukuh Sibetan became ‘seed-savers’ and have worked to make their diversity of salak species their specialty. The locals have also developed a cottage industry making Bali’s only salak wine, sweet and surprisingly tasty! The village itself is quiet and traditional, blessed with cool, clean air and a feeling of true serenity. A stroll around the village roads offers breathtakingly beautiful vistas of mountains, palm trees, ant-like villages and in the distance, the blue ocean. Dukuh Sibetan is comprised of and surrounded by, salak gardens and forest, riddled with tiny paths. A beautiful pond, full of stories and mythology, sits at the bottom of a high cliff dripping with vines and spring water. The villagers invite you to try and feel the spirit of the place. ***************** Each trip to Dukuh Sibetan is different, depending on your interests and the activities of the villagers at the time of your booking. A tailor made plan will be made in consultation with you, prior to departure. Activities you may choose from in Dukuh Sibetan include: - Learning about the cultivation of salak and the making of salak wine. Follow a farmer into their garden, ducking under the salak trees but stay close – the trees are a bit scary looking! Pick a few salak to try and let yourself be immersed in the stories of the life of a salak farmer. The livelihood of the whole village depends on this one fruit, with its brown scaly skin and sweet white flesh. - Strolling through the village with your guide. This is your opportunity to hear about the unique aspects of Dukuh Sibetan history and culture. You will also learn about the natural resource management issues in the village. Stop to explore the village temple and salak plantation, and enjoy the incredible view afforded by the altitude! - Forest-garden trekking. Delve into the trees, and let your guide tell you about the variety of plants you see on the way- some of which are medicinal, some ceremonial, and some which have special cultural beliefs attached to them. You'll stop at the idyllic pond, and you can picnic here if you like, and hear the local stories about the place. Photography is permitted, and this is also an ideal spot for meditation or painting. Be aware that the paths are rough and sometimes steep and slippery. - Special invitation for women travelers only: learn about the lives of women in the village. The activities of the women in Dukuh Sibetan are closely tied to their natural environment. You are invited to spend the day with one of the village 'Ibu' (women), and help her with her daily routine such as cooking, preparing offerings for ceremonies, taking care of the salak garden and children and collecting water. By the end of the day you might understand what the women mean when they say that they work willingly and selflessly in homage to their gods and to nature. Although, they say, help from the men is always welcome! - Help prepare the village for a ceremony or festival. The village is a flurry of activity before a traditional or religious festival, women preparing the hundreds of traditional decorations and men cooking the special foods. By being involved in the preparation, you will gain a greater appreciation of the ceremony when it begins, and feel rightfully proud of your labour!
strTitle: Discover the Serene Mountain Village of Dukuh Sibetan

strIntroduction: Enjoy a cultural bonding experience with your child by learning the basics of silversmithing together. You will learn using traditional techniques with our master Indonesian silversmiths. This is a great beginners class and an excellent introduction to making silver jewelry. This class runs for 3 hours and is a fun, easy-going introduction into the world of jewelry. With the help of our master silversmiths, you will each be able to make your very own design into a finished piece and bring it with you to cherish forever. You and your child will be able to keep this wearable memory forever! Techniques covered in this class include: - Sawing - Soldering - Stamping - Sanding and polishing - Working with silver
strTitle: Bond with your Child through Making Jewelry

strIntroduction: Explore the amazing patterns from the diverse cultures in Indonesia through beadweaving! Learn how to use a beading loom to create a woven beaded bracelet based off traditional Indonesian fabric patterns like Ikat or be inspired to create your very own design. Our bead weaving class runs about 3 hours. In this class you will learn how to lay out your design on paper first and select the colored beads you want to work with. We will help you set up your beading loom and select the beads you want to work with. You will then be guided how to weave your pattern into a bracelet. Finally we will show you how to put the finishing touches and clasp on so you can wear your bracelet. You get to take the jewelry you make with you. This is a great class to take and make a present for a friend as well. After you leave you can take your knowledge with you and keep on bead weaving from home!
strTitle: Become a Master in Beadweaving

strIntroduction: My mission with this class is to provide you with the knowledge, skills, inspiration and motivation required to embark on a healthy, vibrant, raw food-powered lifestyle. One of my favorite ways to do this is to teach people Raw Food Nutrition and Raw Food Freeshing in an intimate setting (my home) where you can see hands on just how easy it can be to make delicious, healthy food that supports your ideal lifestyle and life mission. This particular class is one of my favorites because Durian is my favorite food in the world! The class will consist of us covering 6 Raw Durian Delicacy Recipes like : Durian Passionfruit Pie Durian Chocolate Fudge Creamy Durian Ranch Dressing At the end of the class, you will be able to take home a book of recipes so you can replicate these delicious dishes at home!
strTitle: Learn to Create Raw Durian Delicacies in Ubud

strIntroduction: Bali is not only about beaches and works of art. There are many other interesting and beautiful aspects to our culture, namely our ancient relationship with the natural world. Many of us live in line with the concept of TRI HITA KARANA, which commits us to respecting and working harmoniously with humanity, nature and the Divine. For centuries, we have used a wide range of native plants and herbs for therapeutic, medicinal and health enhancing purposes. On this herb walk, I will take you on a journey around Ubud to explore the prolific plant life that flourishes here. In fact, the name Ubud comes from the word 'ubad', meaning 'medicine', because so many medicinal plants spread wildly in the rice fields. Along the way, I will take you away from the bustle of town, to a hidden place where you will see the natural smiles of farmers planting rice. . You will breathe unpolluted air in nature and I will point out a number of plants used in traditional Balinese medicines and cooking. Familiarize yourself with a wide range of native plants and herbs as I teach you how to make identifications by sight, smell and taste. Along the way, we will also visit an organic farm where we get to see fruits, vegetables and herbs grown without the use of pesticides. Be amazed as local farmers skillfully climb up coconut trees to pick you a coconut to quench your thirst. You will also have the opportunity to taste some delicious jajan (or Balinese local cakes). The journey across the green rice fields with various crops will take a little over 2 hours, with stops along the way to rest, enjoy the scenery and take as many pictures as you'd like.
strTitle: Be one with Nature on a Special Herbal Walk in Ubud

strIntroduction: While there might not be a great number of octopi under the sea around Ceningan Island, there is an awful lot of garden. Or more specifically, seaweed farms. Seaweed is the mainstay of the population of Ceningan and it can be seen everywhere, spread colorfully on tarpaulins, drying in the sun. Ceningan is tucked behind the bigger, touristy island of Lembongan on Bali’s east coast. Life here is hot and relaxed. The seaweed farmers get up early to go out to sea, and rest in the heat of the early afternoon. Later, as the day cools, they go out again, and their boats can be seen crowding around their plantations, like a floating marketplace. Ceningan’s residents have had to fight for this life however. A few years ago the local government proposed to sell the island to resort developers. Only unwavering local opposition stopped the plan, a win for both the community and the environment. Ceningan is small and at certain times of the year, quite dry. Water supply is becoming an issue. Yet Ceningan is extremely pretty. Exploring the island, from the coral reef on the eastern tip to the cave of nesting swallows on the western, with lots of stops for chats with friendly locals in between, makes for a wonderful day. ************** Each trip to Ceningan is different, depending on your interests and the activities of the villagers at the time of your booking. A tailor made plan will be made in consultation with you, prior to departure. Activities you may choose from in Ceningan include: - You can swim, snorkel and surf to your heart's content. See a stunning array of fish and coral in the clear waters on the eastern tip of the island, or look for waves on the pounding southwestern coasts. Snorkeling gear is available, but brings your own surfboard. - Go out with a farmer to see the seaweed plantations by foot or canoe. Learn how the seaweed is tied to frames to grow, and how it is harvested. If you're game, have a go of carrying a basket of seaweed on your head, local style. - Visit the swallow cave at sunset to see the swallows dart in and out of their nesting site. Learn about the strategy for sustainable management of the site (the nests are sometimes harvested for sale to other countries). This is an amazing place to watch the waves crashing below. - Take it easy with the locals – wander around the island, sit on the bamboo resting platforms or siesta with the Ceningan folk. If you're ever stuck for conversation topics, try seaweed…
strTitle: Visit a Seaweed Farm on a Serene Island near Bali
